nodes.bodyText:
Just you think that it is in any situation possible for #getInputStream to return NULL, please catch a NPE here too.
Also I would recommend to call the IOException variable "ignored".

This is maybe beside the point of this PR, but I was wondering this before:
Why are these parameters HttpUrlConnections?
The only method you call on them is #getOutputStream() right?
Thus, they should be UrlConnection instances, I think.

I'm not too familiar with this pattern.
Are OutputStreams always AutoCloseable?

Please move the calls to .toString().getBytes("UTF-8") outside of this method.
This method should have one "single responsibility":
Writing some content to a stream (and not do transformations on that content).
===============
If you want to remove code duplication for these methods,
you should name this method appropriately, example"
#writeJsonToOpenConnection()
Even better would be to create a new method with the above name
which does the transformation and then calls this existing method that writes to the given UrlConnection.
String content instead of JSONObject jsonObject
in a future CL we should probably remove this code duplication

nodes.bodyText:
Probably this is not an issue, but I just want to make sure that we are not running into an issue here:
If outputStream is NULL this will not cause an error when Java is trying to close the stream, right?
Did you test this?

I wonder if this creates more confusion than clarity. What do you think?
Maybe it's better to just say throws IOException and explain in the JavaDoc (or even an inline comment) that it is a UnsupportedEncodingException?

Where is the JSONException thrown? How about catching this JSONException where it is thrown and throw an IllegalStateException instead. That way this method even becomes cleaner and we have less code duplication (of catching this exception).
If you do, please add in JavaDoc of this comment that it might throw an IllegalStateException in case there is a problem with the JSON.
Saw this again. Happy to chat offline.
